University and the Ngee Ann College are from West Malaysia, and how much financial aid is received by those two institutions from the Malaysian Government.

    The Malaysian Government has not given any grant to these two institutions to subsidise their students studying: in these two institutions. UNIVERSITIES OF SINGAPORE
AND MALAYA
(Student population and financial aid)


    2. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Education if he has information (a) how many students in the University of Singapore are from West Malaysia, and how many Singapore students there are in the University of Malaya; and (b) how much financial aid is given by

Column: 685

the Malaysian Government to the University of Singapore and by the Singapore Government to the University of Malaya.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, there are 641 students from West Malaysia studying at the University of Singapore, and 86 Singapore students studying at the University of Malaya. The Malaysian Government has never given to the University of Singapore any financial aid as such. Any contribution made by the Malaysian Government was in respect of the cost of educating Malaysian students studying in the Singapore University. Similarly, the Singapore Government also made contributions to the University of Malaya to meet the cost of educating our students there.

    Prior to the separation of the then University of Malaya into two separate universities, the Singapore Government and the Federation of Malaya Government jointly contributed on an agreed formula towards defraying the cost of running the University which serves students from both territories. The outstanding contributions from the Malaysian Government, on behalf of their students studying in the University of Singapore for the years 1962 to 1966, were discussed and concluded at official level recently and official confirmation is awaited from the Malaysian Government. As a result of these discussions, a sum of $20 million was accepted as the liability for Malaysian students studying in the University of Singapore between the years 1962 and 1966. Of this, an advance payment of $10 million was made in December 1965. The Singapore Government also agreed to settle in full all outstanding dues and claims on behalf of Singapore students studying in the University of Malaya. In the case of Singapore students studying in the University of Malaya in Kuala Lumpur, the contributions have been outstanding for the years 1964 to 1966. This settlement, when confirmed, will conclude all outstanding inter-University financial matters up to the end of this year. For 1967 it has been proposed that a joint Treasury Committee

Column: 686

be set up to re-examine all contributions to the two Universities by the respective Governments on a revised basis reflecting present-day conditions. I understand this proposal has been favourably received.

ALLEGATIONS BY PUBLIC DAILY-RATED
EMPLOYEES' UNIONS FEDERATION
(Appointment of Commission of Inquiry)


    3. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Finance if consideration will be given to appointing a Commission of Inquiry headed by a High Court Judge to inquire into the allegations by the Public Daily-Rated Employees' Unions Federation about the implementation by Government of the 1961 Agreement, and, among other things, (i) to determine whether there has been delay in the implementation of the aforesaid Agreement and whether it has been fully implemented; (ii) to determine whether there had been adequate and competent handling of the dispute with, and the grievances of, the aforesaid Federation; and (iii) to recommend ways and means of settling all grievances within the context of a thorough re-organisation of public service departments, particularly the Cleansing Department of the Ministry of Health, with the view to increasing productivity and efficiency of the public services.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr S. Ramaswamy) (for the Minister for Finance): I am sure the Member for Bras Basah, as Secretary-General of the N.T.U.C., is aware that the Commission of Inquiry, set up in 1963 under the chairmanship of the Commissioner for Labour to investigate the allegations by the Federation on the non-implementation of the 1961 Agreement, made a thorough study of the matter and has made a number of specific recommendations. All these recommendations of the Commission were accepted and implemented by Government. There were a number of disputed grades on which even the Commission was not in a position to make direct

Column: 687

recommendations and, as the Member is aware, on the instructions of the Prime Minister, steps were taken to try to effect a speedy remedy. Settlement was reached on a number of these disputed grades. A few remaining disputed grades and grievance procedure were amongst the subjects which the representatives of the N.T.U.C. and the Federation discussed with the Prime Minister on 6th December. The Prime Minister has indicated at the meeting that there could be further negotiations on these outstanding matters, failing which the matters could be referred to him for a settlement. As a Commission of Inquiry was appointed in 1963 to look into the matter which the Member for Bras Basah has raised, I do not see any reason for another Commission of Inquiry to be appointed.

    As regards a thorough re-organisation of public service departments to settle grievances, the Member knows that a grievance procedure was the subject of discussion between Government, the Federation and the N.T.U.C, as a result of instructions of the Prime Minister to which I have referred. Proposals for a fair and reasonable grievance procedure which does not block or hinder management are already with the Federation and the N.T.U.C. As far as the Cleansing Department of the Ministry of Health is concerned, the Prime Minister informed the N.T.U.C. and the Federation at the meeting on 6th December that a two-shift system would be introduced as from 3rd January, 1967, with a view to increasing the efficiency and productivity of that Department. This would also enable cleansing workers to enjoy Sundays and public holidays as days of rest in future.

    The question of increasing productivity and efficiency of the public service cannot be resolved without a fundamental change in the discipline and supervision of the workers and the attitude of labour leaders towards productivity and efficiency. Unless there is a basic desire by workers to relate earnings to productivity and efficiency, it will not be possible to achieve the

Column: 688

objective. The basic economic and financial realities facing the Republic in the next two years demand that income may only be increased when it is earned through efficiency and productivity.

TRAFFIC LIGHTS AND ZEBRA CROSSINGS


    4. Mr Bernard Rodrigues asked the Minister of State (Prime Minister's Department) if he will consider (a) the installation of traffic lights at the junctions of (i) Kampong Bahru Road/Keppel Road/Telok Blangah Road and (ii) Nelson Road/Keppel Road; and (b) the establishment of zebra crossings at Telok Blangah Road (i) in front of Gate No. 10 and (ii) in front of the Kampong Jagoh Malay School.

    Tuan Haji Yaacob Bin Mohamed(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, the volume of traffic along Keppel Road is fairly heavy, whereas it is negligible on Kampong Bahru Road. A "Halt" sign is installed along Kampong Bahru Road and its junction with Keppel Road. Vehicles from Kampong Bahru Road can filter left into Keppel Road without any difficulty at all. However, vehicles intending to turn right into Keppel Road will have to wait for a short while for a break in the flow of traffic, which is very frequent, to negotiate a right turn. The expense to be incurred in installing a traffic light is not justified and it is not proposed to install a traffic light at this junction.

    (a) (ii) Traffic Light at Nelson Road/Keppel Road

    A traffic light at Nelson Road/Keppel Road junction is not proposed for similar reasons. The volume of traffic is even more negligible than that of Kampong Bahru Road.

    (b) (i) Zebra Crossing along Telok Blangah Road outside Gate No. 10, Port of Singapore Authority

    The majority of pedestrians crossing this road are the P.S.A. workers. In the morning they cross the road in twos and threes; but in the evening, since the employees finish work at the same time,

Column: 689

about 200 to 300 persons cross the road opposite this gate. This crossing takes place in less than 15 minutes, and once the employees have gone home, very few pedestrians cross the road at this point.

    There are sufficient breaks in the flow of traffic to allow pedestrians safe crossing. A zebra crossing cannot be located opposite Gate No. 10 because of the existing taxi stand and the S.T.C. bus terminus. If a zebra crossing is to be located along Telok Blangah Road, it will have to be located at least 300 feet away from Gate No. 10 and the pedestrians will not take the trouble to walk all this distance to cross the road. It is therefore not proposed to have a zebra crossing.

    (b) (ii) Zebra Crossing along Telok Blangah Road outside Kampong Jagoh Malay School

    Other than students, the number of pedestrians crossing Keppel Road is very negligible - an occasional villager crossing the road to the bus stop.

    A school crossing patrolman is employed at this school to assist the children in crossing the road.

    In view of this, there is no justification in providing a zebra crossing.

    Head 0103 -

    Mr Tang See Chim (Choa Chu Kang): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0103 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (3) of subhead 2001.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, we have a cosy air-conditioned library, a charming and helpful Librarian, but alas no books - hardly any books. I was trying to do some research the other day on the Finance Minister's Budget Speech and I found that there was only one title on public finance. There are no books on economics at all, none on sociology, a handful on the parliamentary system, hardly any on the comparative system of government and practically none on politics. There is not even a set of Encyclopaedia Britannica or a set of encyclopaedia on the social sciences.

2.45 p.m.

    I noticed from the Suggestion Book in the Library that in 1961 a Member did suggest that the Library acquire a set of Encyclopaedia Britannica, but this suggestion was turned down by the then House Committee, by a majority, but without giving any reasons. Possibly the then House Committee consisted of Members who had no use for reference books!

    Mr Speaker, Sir, you will agree with me that the present stock of books in the Library is hardly adequate. This lack of reference material hampers the work of hon. Members, and this year's estimate of a miserable sum of $800 is hardly sufficient to meet the situation. From a cursory look into the estimates on the book votes for other departments, most of the departments, however minor, appear to have a larger vote for books than Parliament. I will just give a few examples: the book vote for Postal Services, $920; for Civil Aviation, $2,000; for the Trade Division, $1,250 and for the Foreign Ministry, $6,000. This small vote for books for Parliament is surely an unnecessary handicap to Members and I strongly urge the Minister for Finance to remedy it.

    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, Sir, I myself am in sympathy with the Member for

Column: 691

Choa Chu Kang when he found that our Library is inadequate for his own needs.

    We are happy indeed to have an active Member like him who will possibly make suggestions to the House Committee on the types of books which he thinks Members of Parliament ought to read to improve the standard of their debate and the amount of information which they ought to acquire. However, I would like to point out that the Librarian is always at the service of Members of Parliament, and if there are Members who wish to obtain books for their reading which are not available in the Library here, she would be only too happy to secure them from the National Library. We must, however, remember that we do not wish to duplicate the National Library in Parliament House and, therefore, the Library in Parliament House is a specialised one. The books which we find in our Library are those relating to constitutional law, Keesing's Contemporary Archives which give you an up-to-date account of current events, and there are many other forms of literature which I am quite sure will be very useful to all those Members who wish to extract information to help them.

    As far as books on economics, commerce, maybe accountancy too or the social sciences are concerned, I myself have felt that we are lacking in these, and I hope the House Committee can put forward suggestions and make recommendations to the Ministry of Finance. I am quite sure the Minister for Finance will be sympathetic and grant the House Committee a supplementary vote next year if it is found that the vote in this Budget is inadequate. As far as the encyclopaedias --- Encyclopaedia Britannica or Encyclopaedia of social sciences or any type - are concerned, I am in agreement with the Member for Choa Chu Kang that we could very well do with these books as they are very useful sources of information.

    To end, I only hope that all Members of Parliament will put forward their suggestions to the House Committee on how the Library position can be improved and we will look at them with sympathy.

    Sir, may I know what are these President's Scholarships, for whom and why are they under the name of the President?

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, in former days there used to be scholarships open to candidates on the basis of competitive examinations, and the winners of these scholarships were given sufficient funds to travel to almost any university where they wished to receive training. We decided, as from 1966, to reinstitute these scholarships which were previously known as Queen's Scholarships. These scholarships, which were highly prized by successive generations of students, were instrumental in getting a small corps of able and highly-trained men into several of the professions then open. With the establishment of the University of Singapore, these scholarships were transferred to the University to be used by way of post-graduate courses. However, my colleagues and I have for some time been rather concerned with the problems which have not altogether been resolved in the University, in throwing up people who not only have the academic training and intellectual discipline, but also qualities of leadership and an interest in matters outside their particular field of discipline. We have therefore reinstituted this scholarship at the Higher School Certificate level and all winners of the

Column: 694

scholarship, of which there are nine this year, can choose to go to any university to which they can get admission, and their expenses will be met by the Government. They are known as President's Scholars to denote that they are people who have won signal distinction for themselves to merit special privileges for further education. As a rule, the President's Scholar is usually able to get some other scholarship. In fact, what happens is that he gets all his fees and expenses met by some other scholarship which he has won, and in the end is granted an allowance of £50 sterling per annum in addition to the other allowances that he gets. In this way, it is hoped to continue a supply of men not only well qualified and competent in their own fields of study but with all the social and other graces which make for the difficult to define quality called leadership.

I was wondering how this £50 per annum would help towards maintaining a student in the pursuit of his studies in a university.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, I am afraid I may not have made myself sufficiently clear. There are nine scholarships open to the nine best students from the H.S.C. classes of all language streams. The winners of these scholarships can choose to go to any university anywhere in the world to which they can gain admission. If they do not gain any other scholarship, then the Government will pay their passage to that university, their tuition fees, and their subsistence cost. But the students who win these scholarships usually also win other scholarships, and when they do that, as a mark of distinction over and above the other students who have won similar scholarships, they get an additional £50 per annum.

    I am not suggesting that any student anywhere in the world can survive on £50 per annum, but the £50 is only given to the student who has, before he gets the President's scholarship, already qualified

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I am glad to note that Singapore students are still allowed to stay in Malaysia Hall in London and that the Government is still continuing to contribute towards its running expenses. I have very vivid memories of my stay in Malaysia Hall. It was then called Malaya Hall. cost in acquiring the premises of Malaysia Hall, and we have since then paid one-third of the recurrent expenditure annually for its upkeep.     Mr Speaker, Sir, our children who attend Primary One classes and complete their studies after taking their Malaysian Certificate of Education or Cambridge examinations increase year by year. Likewise the number of industries also increases and needs workers of high calibre. If the Government wants Malay children to have high qualifications in order that they can compete with non-Malays, whether in education or other fields, and also wants an increasing number of Malays to receive higher education, then it should increase the vote for 1967. Instead, it has been reduced. Could the Prime Minister explain the reason for the reduction in the vote for 1967 as compared with 1966?

    Mr Lingam: I am not speaking, Sir.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, the short and direct answer to the query posed by the Member for Kampong Kembangan is that a number of bursaries to certain Nanyang University students have been cancelled. We provide bursaries to our students in order that they will make a contribution to higher learning, higher discipline, and ultimately a higher level of economic activity in our country. But when students take advantage of these facilities not in order to promote the welfare of the community but to bring

Column: 698

into disrepute the institutions of higher learning to which they gain admission, then I think it is the duty of the Government to terminate these bursaries.

    First, I want to point out to Members generally that there is a distinction between a scholarship and a bursary. I have pointed out that the best of all the scholarships which we give are now known as the President's scholarships. A scholarship is awarded on the basis of merit regardless of the financial standing of the parents of the student. But if all students can get assistance only on the basis of higher academic performance, then a large body of very good but less than brilliant students would be denied this opportunity. Therefore, a large number of students are given assistance by what are known as bursaries. For the award of a bursary, other considerations, besides just academic competence, are taken into consideration. First, the financial capacity of the parents of the student; second, the subject which the student wishes to pursue. If the subject is one which is likely to make a contribution to our society, then a bursary will be more readily forthcoming. The amount of the bursary given to the student will depend upon the financial resources of his parents. The wealthier the parent or the more he can afford, the less the State will assist.

    As for Malay students, I would like to point out that we are continuing our policy of giving free education from primary school to university to all Singapore citizens who are Malays and can obtain admission to these institutions of learning. The reduction in the sum in no way affects the number of pupils who will be getting scholarships or bursaries from Malay secondary schools to higher institutions of learning.
